IMPEDIMENT.deftext:
an obstacle, obstruction, hindrance

The verb IMPEDE comes from the Latin word for foot, which is also the source of the English words pedal and pedestrian. The original Latin meaning of IMPEDE was “to snare the feet.” Today it means more generally “to obstruct the progress of,” to hinder.

“The constant floods IMPEDED their journey.” An IMPEDIMENT is something which IMPEDES, an obstacle.

“Lack of money was the main IMPEDIMENT to the successful completion of the project.”

“He had a speech IMPEDIMENT that kept him from talking easily.”

Other forms of the word: IMPEDE,v.

DORMANT.deftext:
inactive

DORMANT comes originally from a Latin word meaning to sleep, also the source of the word dormitory. DORMANT means lying asleep or as if asleep. It is used about things which are inactive now, but are capable of becoming active in the future.

“During the winter, trees become DORMANT. In the spring they seem to come alive again and put out new leaves.”

“After years of being DORMANT the volcano suddenly erupted.”

“Her ability to paint lay DORMANT for many years. She didn’t start to draw and sketch until she was past fifty.”

DIMINISH.deftext:
to lessen, decrease, dwindle

To DIMINISH is to make less, or to become less.

“Nothing could DIMINISH my interest in history.”

“The value of our house DIMINISHED when they decided to build an expressway next to it.”

“His wealth DIMINISHED as a result of poor investments.”

“Our food supply was greatly DIMINISHED by the end of the day.”

The most common wrong answer on the Pretest is stop.

To DIMINISH something is not to stop it, though,only to lessen it.

JAUNT.deftext:
a short trip, excursion

A JAUNT is a short, casual trip taken for pleasure.

“We took a quick JAUNT to the beach.”

“They went on a JAUNT to see the city sights.”

JAUNT can also be used as a verb.

“She liked to JAUNT through the lovely parks. ”

TUMULT.deftext:
an uproar, noise, disturbance, commotion

A TUMULT is any sort of uproar or disturbance.

“The politician was greeted with a TUMULT of cheers.”

“There was a sudden silence in the midst of the TUMULT.”

TUMULT is often used about highly disturbed emotions.

“Her feelings were in a TUMULT as she waited for the door to open.”

The adjective form of TUMULT is TUMULTUOUS, which means noisy or disorderly.

“The star received TUMULTUOUS applause when he came on stage.”

“The teacher tried to calm the TUMULTUOUS crowd of children.”

Other forms of the word: TUMULTUOUS,adj.

CLAD.deftext:
dressed, clothed

CLAD is an old form of the past tense of the verb to clothe. When the word is used in this way, it usually has an old-fashioned flavor.

“The princess was CLAD in the finest Japanese silk.”

Usually CLAD is an adjective, used with another word as part of a phrase.

“Poorly CLAD beggars roamed the streets of the town.”

An IRONCLAD ship is covered with iron plates, usually as armor. From this IRONCLAD has come to be used about anything that is impossible to break.

“We had an IRONCLAD agreement to help each other.”

MERCANTILE.deftext:
related to trade, commercial

A MERCHANT is someone who buys and sells a product for profit. MERCANTILE is an adjective from MERCHANT and means “of or related to MERCHANTS or trading.”

“It was a MERCANTILE city, famous for its many large businesses.”

“The MERCANTILE interests in the legislature sup- ported all bills that would help increase trade.”

Other forms of the word: MERCHANT, n.

ANGUISH.deftext:
suffering, sorrow, distress, woe, agony

ANGUISH is extreme suffering. The suffering can be either mental or physical.

“Her son’s death in an automobile accident caused her great ANGUISH.”

“Nothing we could do could relieve her ANGUISH when her house burned down.”

“The soldier was in ANGUISH until the doctor came to treat his wound.”

ANGUISH is also a verb.

“Mary ANGUISHED over the loss of her home and belongings in the fire.”

ANGUISHED is the adjective from ANGUISH.

“Her ANGUISHED cries told us that something was terribly wrong.”

Rage is the incorrect answer that is most often chosen. This is probably due to a confusion between ANGUISH and anger. Other forms of the word: ANGUISHED, adj.

DEPLORABLE.deftext:
wretched, bad, causing grief or regret

To DEPLORE something is to feel great regret, disapproval, or sorrow about it.

“He DEPLORED the conditions in which the miners had to work.”

DEPLORABLE is the adjective from DEPLORE. Something which is DEPLORABLE is wretched, bad enough to cause strong disapproval.

“When we arrived at our new apartment we found that the people living there before us had left it in a DE- PLORABLE condition.” “Wendy’s grandmother told her that her manners were DEPLORABLE.”

Sometimes the word is used about something that causes sorrow rather than disapproval.

“The people wept bitterly upon hearing of the DEPLORABLE death of their president.”

“They had never before witnessed such a DEPLORABLE accident.” Other forms of the word: DEPLORE, v.

EFFERVESCENT.deftext:
bubbling, exuberant, lively

The ferv part of EFFERVESCENT comes from a Latin word meaning to boil, also the source of the word fervent. To EFFERVESCE is to give off bubbles of gas the way a carbonated soft drink or champagne does.EFFERVES- CENT is the adjective from EFFERVESCE. The word is usually used in a general sense about people who are so lively and excitable that they seem to bubbleover with enthusiasm, joy, or ideas.

“Her EFFERVESCENT enthusiasm made everyone else try twice as hard.”

“His EFFERVESCENT personality would enliven any party.”

“Jane’s EFFERVESCENT imagination came up with a hundred ways of solving the problem.”

Other forms of the word: EFFERVESCE, v. EFFERVESCENCE, n.

ORNATE.deftext:
elaborately or excessively decorated, showy

ORNATE is related to the word ornament. Something which is ORNATE is highly decorated or ornamented.

“The chair was very ORNATE, covered with scrolls and designs and patterns.”

“We stared at the ORNATE design on the ceiling of the church.”

ORNATE is often used about writing which is full of flowery language.

“Some people like this ORNATE style of writing. I like writing to be simple and clear.”

SOMBER.deftext:
gloomy, dark, dark colored, dismal

SOMBER means gloomy, dark, or shadowy. It is used about things and people’s moods.

“It was customary for relatives of the dead person to dress in SOMBER clothes for at least a year.”

“SOMBER clouds filled the sky.”

“She put on a SOMBER look, even though she was secretly pleased.”

“He couldn’t shake off his SOMBER mood.”

Many people think SOMBER means bored. SOMBER, however, emphasizes gloominess and depression rather than boredom.

JURISDICTION.deftext:
authority, power, control

JURISDICTION comes from the Latin word for law, also the source of jury. JURISDICTION is the legal power to administer justice and decide cases. “Our courts have JURISDICTION over foreigners living in the United States.”

“The judge said it wasn’t within his JURISDICTION to decide this question.”

The word can be used in a broader sense for any authority or power that has well-defined limits.

“Your complaint does not come within our JURISDICTION. Try another department.”

The most popular wrong answer is decision. People who choose this probably know that JURISDICTION has something to do with the law, but don’t know exactly what. JURISDICTION is the authority to make a legal decision, not the decision itself.

NARRATIVE.deftext:
a story, tale To NARRATE a story is to tell it.

“He NARRATED a story about a boy and his dog living on a farm.”

A NARRATIVE is a story, the telling of a series of events.

A NARRATIVE can be either true or made up.

“They read an exciting NARRATIVE about pirates and buried treasure.”

“We listened to the NARRATIVE of the first space- flight.”

Other forms of the word: NARRATE, v. NARRATOR, n.

REALM.deftext:
a kingdom, territory, region

REALM is a fancy or poetical word for kingdom.

“The king searched throughout his REALM for one honest man.”

The word is also used in a general sense for region, territory, or range.

“He lived entirely within the REALM of his own imagination.”

If something is “within the REALM of possibility,” it is possible, it can happen.

The most commonly chosen wrong answer is tale, possibly because REALM is connected in people’s minds with stories and legends rather than with everyday speech.

questions.prompt: In the middle of the TUMULT.
Would a train be IMPEDED by a truck on the tracks?
Are some bears DORMANT during the winter?
Does your supply of money DIMINISH when you spend some?
Could someone go on a JAUNT to the zoo?
Would a riot be considered a TUMULT?
Would a well-CLAD person have holes in his socks?
Would someone who sells furniture be called a MERCHANT?
Do people enjoy being in ANGUISH?
Are people generally SOMBER at a wedding?
Does the teacher have JURISDICTION in the classroom?
Can a NARRATIVE be very short?
Does a king rule a REALM?
If there are no unexpected IMPEDIMENTS, we should be finished on time.
My talent for writing was DORMANT for many years until a friend in publishing persuaded me to write a book.
The wrecking crew completely DIMINISHED the building in a few hours.
Magellan's JAUNT around the world lasted several years.
They were so ashamed of themselves that they just stood there in TUMULTUOUS silence.
The knight was CLAD in shining armor.
Some commercial banks discourage small savings accounts; they prefer to deal with large MERCANTILE outfits.
I will never forget the ANGUISHED look on his face when his dog died.
She thought the dirty language in the movie was DEPLORABLE.
These problems are EFFERVESCENT; I don't think we'll ever solve them.
The stained glass window was beautifully ORNATE. It would take you hours to notice all the details.
The hotel was filled with SOMBER, poorly lit passageways that made us feel a little frightened.
After many days of debate the jury finally reached a JURISDICTION.
. They listened to the exciting NARRATIVE of his adventures.
The teacher said that my getting an A in English was not within the REALM of possibility.
